metadata.case_name: Dr. Shamlal Narula v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Appellant, Dr. Shamlal Narula, is the Manager of a Hindu undivided family which owned 40 bighas and 11 biswas of land in Patiala.
Patiala State Government initiated land acquisition proceedings under regulations in pari materia with Land Acquisition Act, 1894.
Patiala State merged into Union of PEPSU, which later merged into State of Punjab; Land Acquisition Act extended to PEPSU on October 6, 1953.
Collector of Patiala made award under the Act on September 30, 1955; appellant received Rs. 2,81,822 on December 1, 1955, including Rs. 48,660 as interest up to date of award.
For assessment year 1956-57, Income-tax Officer included Rs. 48,660 interest in income of HUF and assessed to tax, overruling contention that it was capital receipt.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO order on June 14, 1957.
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal on July 9, 1957 held interest was capital receipt and excluded from total income.
At instance of Commissioner, Tribunal referred question to Punjab High Court under s.66(1) Income-tax Act, 1922: Whether Rs. 48,660 was capital receipt not liable to tax.
Punjab High Court Division Bench held amount was revenue receipt liable to tax; judgment dated January 31, 1962.
Appeal to Supreme Court by certificate granted by High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether interest paid under s. 34 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 is a capital receipt or revenue receipt.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sum of Rs. 48,660 received under award was compensation for depriving him of right to possession of property and therefore capital receipt not liable to tax.
Where possession taken before award, interest under s. 34 takes character of compensation for depriving owner of right to possession.

respondent_arguments.text: Order of High Court to be sustained for reasons stated therein.

court_reasoning.text: s. 34 distinguishes between compensation awarded and interest payable thereon at 6% from taking possession until payment; interest pertains to payment after compensation ascertained.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Interest is consideration for use of money or forbearance, not part of compensation.

court_reasoning.text: Compensation under ss. 23-24 does not include interest; interest provided separately in Part V under 'Payment'.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act makes clear distinction between compensation for land and interest on it.

court_reasoning.text: After possession taken (under s.16 or s.17), title vests in Government; claimant entitled only to compensation, interest for Government's withholding of it.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No difference if possession before or after award; interest for use of money by State.

court_reasoning.text: Word 'interest' in s.34 to be given natural meaning; represents profit from use of money or loss from not having it.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Quotes Westminster Bank Ltd. v. Riches on nature of interest as compensation for detention of money.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Behari Lal Bhargava: interest not compensation for loss of possession as title vests on possession.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Interest only for keeping back compensation amount.

court_reasoning.text: Agrees with Madras HC in CIT v. Narayanan Chettiar declining to follow Behari Lal; cites other cases supporting interest as taxable income.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Statutory interest taxable like other interest.

holdings.text: Interest under s.34 Land Acquisition Act is revenue receipt liable to income-tax, not capital receipt.

precedents_cited.relevance: Illuminating exposition of 'interest' as compensation for deprivation of use of money.

precedents_cited.case_name: Behari Lal Bhargava v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Held interest under s.28 as capital; court disagrees as title vests on possession.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. CT. RM. N. Narayanan Chettiar
precedents_cited.relevance: Declined to follow Behari Lal; interest taxable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Maharajadhiraj Sir Kameshwar Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Interest under s.18A Income-tax Act taxable; refused to follow Behari Lal.
Principle that statutory interest is taxable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Barnato
precedents_cited.relevance: Principle that statutory interest is taxable.

precedents_cited.case_name: P. V. Kurien v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Kerala
precedents_cited.relevance: Held interest on enhanced compensation as capital; text cuts off but implied disagreement.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition Act, 1894
statutes_cited.relevance: s.34 provides interest on compensation from possession until payment; distinguishes from compensation itself.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference to High Court on taxability.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Punjab High Court holding that Rs. 48,660 interest under s.34 Land Acquisition Act is revenue receipt liable to income-tax; appeal dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "The interest shall be paid on the amount awarded from the time the Collector takes possession until the amount is paid or deposited."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Highlights distinction between compensation and interest in s.34.

key_quotes.text: "Interest is a consideration paid either for the use of the money or forbearance from demanding it after it has fallen due."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines nature of interest as revenue, not capital.

key_quotes.text: "The general idea is that he is entitled to compensation for the deprivation... interest was a compensation... properly described as interest."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Lord Wright from Westminster Bank on true nature of interest.
